query: What actions are available to control or contain invasive Procambarus crayfish populations?
relevant_summary: Several control methods are available for managing invasive Procambarus crayfish populations. Physical barriers such as concrete dams with anti-crawling features can effectively prevent upstream spread of populations (Action 1037). Trapping and removal using food-baited traps is effective, with tinned meat proving more successful than pheromone baits (Action 1029). Biological control through encouraging predators has shown promise, with eels significantly reducing crayfish populations in Italian studies and pike also feeding on them (Action 1030). A combination approach using both trapping and predator encouragement has been found more effective than either method alone (Action 1031). Chemical control using natural pyrethrum (Pyblast at 0.05 mg/l concentration) can kill crayfish, though application to drained burrows is not effective (Action 1036). Electrofishing as a removal method has been tested but no evidence of its effectiveness was found in available studies (Action 1035).

query: Besides adding chemicals, what are some effective, alternative methods for managing invasive Asian clam populations in industrial water systems?
relevant_summary: Several non-chemical methods have shown effectiveness for managing Asian clam populations in water systems. Laboratory studies found that exposing Asian clams to temperatures of 36°C or higher kills them within four days. High salinities (18-34‰) achieved 100% mortality in controlled laboratory conditions. Mechanical removal techniques have demonstrated high effectiveness, with suction dredging reducing clam densities by 96% within sediment over two weeks, and this reduction persisted for a year. Three types of dredges tested in Ireland were equally effective, achieving biomass reductions of 74% to >95% and density reductions of 65% to 95%. Gas-impermeable barriers placed across lake bottoms significantly reduced Asian clam abundance in controlled studies. However, Asian clams showed resistance to extreme low oxygen levels regardless of water temperature or exposure duration, making hypoxia an ineffective management strategy.
